item.title: 微型计算机第二次浪潮
item.description: 1977年，Apple II、Commodore PET 和 TRS-80 组成的“三巨头”横空出世，标志着微型计算机从极客的自制玩物正式转变为面向大众的消费级商品。本文深入回顾了这段历史，重点剖析了 Apple Computer 的崛起之路，从沃兹尼亚克的技术突破到乔布斯的商业远见，以及资本如何助推这一变革，最终开启了个人计算的新时代。

Tablets

December 2010

I was thinking recently how inconvenient it was not to have a general term for iPhones, iPads, and the corresponding things running Android. The closest to a general term seems to be “mobile devices,” but that (a) applies to any mobile phone, and (b) doesn’t really capture what’s distinctive about the iPad.

item.title: Apple's Mistake
item.description:
→ 中文版本

https://www.paulgraham.com/apple.html

Apple’s Mistake

Want to start a startup? Get funded by Y Combinator. November 2009

I don’t think Apple realizes how badly the App Store approval process is broken. Or rather, I don’t think they realize how much it matters that it’s broken.

The way Apple runs the App Store has harmed their reputation with programmers more than anything else they’ve ever done. Their reputation with programmers used to be great. It used to be the most common complaint you heard about Apple was that their fans admired them too uncritically. The App Store has changed that. Now a lot of programmers have started to see Apple as evil.

item.title: Microsoft is Dead
item.description:
→ 中文版本

https://www.paulgraham.com/microsoft.html

Microsoft is Dead

April 2007

A few days ago I suddenly realized Microsoft was dead. I was talking to a young startup founder about how Google was different from Yahoo. I said that Yahoo had been warped from the start by their fear of Microsoft. That was why they’d positioned themselves as a “media company” instead of a technology company. Then I looked at his face and realized he didn’t understand. It was as if I’d told him how much girls liked Barry Manilow in the mid 80s. Barry who? Microsoft? He didn’t say anything, but I could tell he didn’t quite believe anyone would be frightened of them.

item.title: Return of the Mac
item.description:
https://www.paulgraham.com/mac.html

Return of the Mac

March 2005

All the best hackers I know are gradually switching to Macs. My friend Robert said his whole research group at MIT recently bought themselves Powerbooks. These guys are not the graphic designers and grandmas who were buying Macs at Apple’s low point in the mid 1990s. They’re about as hardcore OS hackers as you can get.
